It is a familiar enough story, I suppose. My husband... he was a good man, but weak. He drank, he gambled, he lost our money... a merchant came to our house, we could not pay, and so this merchant asked our daughter in exchange for forgiveness of our debt. I killed him, and then... I had to leave, of course. But before I did... I killed my husband as well, because he would have done the same thing again.

I have been to the West, yes, but my loyalties are here, if you are asking. I am Krax, through and through, in my heart, though because of my travels, I do not share the accent, as you have no doubt noticed. I am seeking new employment, friend - actively seeking, for I lost everything I had recently. It is only through my skill with the staff that I escaped with my life. The caravan I was shepherding... we were en route to a city called Bruze, and these things came out of the desert... they breathed fire upon us. It was like a story out of the old days. Monsters, they were. These are dangerous lands, my friend.

UnitType.Backstory: My story? I was not always a soldier-at-arms. I was a merchant once - my brother and I were partners. We came from Sigidd-Belzen, a town far from here. A town no longer, not since the transformation. Everything changed then - my brother changed then. Something died inside him - money became his god. He made it seem as if I had stolen from another man - he framed me, and I was jailed, and he took all our money, all the wealth and things we had accumulated, and he left. He left me with nothing. I do not have a brother anymore. Well. I have spoken longer than I intended.

GameModifier.Provides: -5% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: 'My story is now interwoven with yours.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: These are dangerous lands... death is never far. For a price, Ruah will walk with you, will bring her dagger to bear where it is needed. Death and I, we are becoming good friends. We met here, in this very place, not long ago. In the ravine there, I came upon a man I knew. His name was Kronyu, he was a simple mill worker, only not so simple as it turns out... you see, there had been some killings in my village. Five murders, and there was great fear among my people, for we thought the sorcerer we had driven out - a man named Meerduul - we thought he had returned. But there in the ravine, on this day... I came upon Kronyu, as I said. Kronyu, and a dead woman. He was holding her in his arms, he had one hand around her throat, and in the other... he held a tool he had taken from the mill. He had driven it through her neck, and he was holding her tightly, so she could not scream. Holding her and staring into her eyes, and there was blood everywhere, and he was just... staring. Staring into the face of death. And when it was done, he dropped her to the ground, and turned, and then he saw me. And you would think I would have been scared, I was no warrior then, but I knew somehow... I was safe. And soon after this... Kronyu and I became lovers. We lived together. He worked at the mill, and some days... he would kill. This we never spoke of, but... I began to wonder. I began to dream. Dreams of dark gods and dying men. Dreams of what it might be like to kill someone, myself. And then one night... Kronyu was sleeping. And through my head ran all the questions about what killing felt like, and I thought first of waking him. But I knew he could not tell me what it felt like with words. And so... I took a knife from near the fire. It was covered in blood, from a chicken we had cooked for our dinner. I took that knife, and I lay down next to Kronyu. Very close. He was warm... I could feel his breath going in and out. I felt the beating of his heart; I smelt the cut wood of the mill on his hair. I slipped the knife into him. Up beneath his ribs. He came awake with a start, and saw me, and ... he tried to move away, but I held him close. He tried to talk, but I covered his mouth. I looked into his eyes, and waited, and after a time... It is strange, I know, to speak of such terrible things. But these are terrible times, my friend. Ruah can help you get through them, you will see.

A kitchen knife, a thief's dirk, a pickpocket's blade... the dagger I was known for, though... that was Antheran steel. Made in the time before this one, friend, crafted in Malaya itself... hardest metal in the land. Go straight through armor, you use it right. Galain took it from me, when he stripped me of the blue. There was no honor in that action, friend, as there was no honor in the Knights' behavior during the Revolt. Tandis himself would never have taken sides in that war. We serve all of mankind, not just this king or that. That's who I wish to serve now - I'll follow you, long as you understand that. Long as you know I have higher goals.

In the time before this one, the Lamord, we were a great merchant family, my great-grandfather, he was a councillor for the Serrane, we had an estate in the hills near the Western Sea, and... those things, they were most of them destroyed in the great affarenze, the Cataclysm, and those that were left - my family's money... you see, when you know fine things... you acquire a taste for them. I acquired a taste for them, and for money, and so I gambled, you see. With what there was left to us, you see, I was reckless. And now there is nothing. My family... they will not speak to me. My sisters, my nephew... they live in a hut. A hut. No. I am determined to make this right. To restore honor to myself, and my family, and yes, to the world. If you give me a chance, I will prove myself, I swear it.

UnitType.Backstory: This bow is of the yrilla tree - it was given to me by the peoples of the jungle, by the Drota. Some say they enchant their weapons, but I believe it to be the wood itself... its color, its strength, its flexibility. It is the perfect killing weapon, to me. Most among my people would not think so. The Quendar believe that death is to be dealt face-to-face - that there is honor only in a killing blow given by your hand, to your enemy at close range. This my father believed, but he and my brothers were slaughtered by D'rog spearmen - Trog warriors - who dared not face them in hand-to-hand combat. As all Quendar must, I have mastered the art of unarmed combat. But my preferred weapon - always - is the bow. I fight not for honor. I fight to kill.

UnitType.Backstory: Fairy tale? Who has told you this? Rahelle's story is no fairy tale, but the simple truth. In the year after the Black Summer, I was forced to cross the deserts of the south alone, on horseback. A day's ride from my home, my mount sickened, and died. I burned in the Sun's fires, and fell into the sands, convinced I had met my end. But the Destiny answered my prayers, and sent to me a thousand scorpions, who bore me upon their backs to the safety of a hermit's cave. Since that day, I have been immune to the scorpion's venom. Since that day, my dagger carries within it the scorpion's sting.

Bruze is - was - great city. City of survivors. City of fighters. But this world... Titans were dangerous, yes, but more dangerous still... the Anthuanii... yes, these things are real, I have seen them... Bruze was near wildlands, great swamp... the Vassyulka, we call it... these creatures come out of swamp, first only a few, but then more and more, and Vazim's brothers are killed, Vasim's family is killed, whole city is gone... dangerous times, my friend. I have fought these things, and they must be destroyed, as the Titans intended. As Curgen intended. You will see this, Vasim is sure. When you do... Vasim is with you. Vasim and his axe.

When I was young, I was stricken with a disease, one that should have killed me, and yet somehow I managed to survive. But afterwards... I was never the same. I spent much time indoors. There was a ruin near our village, a library of sorts. I would go there, and read, rather than play with the other children. The more I learned, the more I wished to know. And that remains true to this day.

UnitType.Backstory: Aye, some say I dress like the barmaid I was once, but it's not my dress you'd be paying me for, is it? I know the worth of a man's work, and a woman's too, and the worth of the things they make, and I know how to get the best out of any deal. And I don't believe in cheating, I believe you don't need to make enemies to make money, you're better off playing fair with anyone you bargain with. My father relied on me from the time I was a young girl to deal with the merchants who came round, and I did that well enough, and then the master of an inn near us, he hired me to do his books, and manage his affairs, and soon enough... well, here I am. Some say I have a silver tongue, and maybe that's so, but I don't think it's trickery to point out the value of a thing.

And I can do better. I can do more. More for you, if you'll have me.

None of them. Not the merchant, nor his brothers, nor his wives, or daughters, or sons. And that is what I and my people learned from Curgen, whose name is undying.

Taught me to fight. I have this sword from them, and I am expert in this use. Hire me. I will show you. I will prove it to you.

UnitType.Quote: 'What passes effortlessly through steel and turns flesh to ash? What cannot be caged and turns night to day? That which I command.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: Some will tell you they fought in the Arena, friend, and that makes them good hires for you. Makes them worth your coin. I'm here to tell you that's wrong. Arena fighting, that's not real fighting. You don't get boundaries out here in the real world. You don't get rules. You don't get someone giving you the word to begin. Out here, wargs'll rip your throat while you're sleeping. Darklings'll spear you from behind without a word of warning. I ought to know; I was raised in the shadow of the Fissure, and things come out of there ain't never been dreamed of in the Arena. Sure, my father fought in the Arena, but his people were from the North, from the Free Cities, and they knew the kinds of things that were out there in the world, even before the Cataclysm. Those things are out there still, friend. You hire me, I'll keep you safe from 'em best I can.

And this one time - I had helped build a palisade protecting our city, and the man who was in charge, I knew he'd done flawed work, but I kept my mouth shut. Kept my mouth shut, and those bandit devils - the Hassainii, I'm sure you've heard tell of them - they ran right over the wall. Knocked it down, no trouble. Ten people died that night, and that was on me as much as anyone. I'll work your people night and day to see things done right.

UnitType.Quote: 'Ars longa, vita brevis.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory:
It was the night of haunted dreams, when Shirayn's scream echoed across the world of Elemental, when the boundary between life and death was torn. A thousand strange things happened that night. In the abattoir of Khaffara blood pooled and ran up the slaughter tables and back into the corpses. Violent whines and thrashing could be heard from a smokehouse in Farcross. In Tarth crows simply fell dead from the sky.
But the most gruesome of these, second only to the pained rebirth of Shirayn herself, was what formed bellow the ancient gallows of Hagudst. For centuries this place had been used for the execution of murderers, traitors and the possessed. Long ago, in an age when a young oracle was locked in a temple, a death cult had been condemned and put to death at the gallows, and their leader swore that death would not stop them, that they would rise again. A noose put an end to their rants, and their corpses were thrown on the bones of the gallows past victims and forgotten.
Their corpses fell to ruin as new corpses buried them, as centuries passed and a cataclysm shook the world, as new empires grew. Until the night of haunted dreams, when the restless spirits of the bone pile finally heard their screams echoed in the world. But these voices no longer had form, there was no single spirit, but an orchestra of suffering and anger. And though a single body rose from the decayed bones and dirt, centuries of spirits went with it.
This Gallowman began walking the dark fields of Elemental, and he was drawn to places of death and pain. The world is full of such places. And though beasts usually avoided him men rarely showed such wisdom. When self-appointed bandit king or foolish hero stopped him Gallowman would reach out to the dead in the area and release the cacophony of spirits he carried with him, allowing them to seek out new forms, to be reborn out of the earth and slaughter the living. And their screaming voices would be dragged back and added to the Gallowman's collection.

It is not a pretty sight, I would not inflict it upon others, and so I wear these robes. They help to hide my staff as well. I am not without power; I have mastered death, in a sense, and so I know how to summon it. Not as a channeler, of course - but I have knowledge of the body, a man's weak points, areas where the veins are close to the surface, where a small cut can inflict great damage, where the bones are fragile, where a certain amount of pressure can kill. These are the skills I can offer - if you are interested.

UnitType.Quote: 'Many will offer you their sword, but none will have a blade like mine.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: Many will offer you their sword, but none will have a blade like mine. You see the edge? Do not touch; the steel will slice through bone like a blade through butter. It was passed on to me by my uncle, who had it from one of the last of the Antheran guardsman; there were jewels in the hilt once, you can see, but they were long ago pried out by thieves. The steel itself has far greater value; it is Antheran, I was told, and will hold its edge forever. I do not brag to tell you I have killed two score with it, man and grayskin alike. And that is another thing I must tell you about myself; a thing that was told to me by a Drota shaman I had chance to meet once, long ago, in a place far from here. She would not share a boat with me, and my family; she claimed I carried an aura about my person, an aura of death. Perhaps she was right, for the very next afternoon, as our ship crossed a span of open sea, a sudden squall capsized us, and all were lost, passengers and crew, save for myself. My parents, my brother... but this aura has taken others as well. In battle. A man I wounded fell backwards, and slipped, and split his head on a rock. I do not know if you take much stock in what shamans and the like have to say; if you do, then there is that to consider as well.

A sad story, a tragedy, the tale of a love that could never be. Ithuane and Pariden. Mortal, and Titan. Is it true? Who knows? But the song... I could sing it for you. I'm a fair singer, not as good as my father was, but then that's all he did. He sang for Procipinee, you know. More than once. Much as she liked his singing, you would think she would have gone after the bastards who killed him with a little more alacrity. I took care of them, though. With my Ithuane, right here. That's what I focus my energies on. The sword. My girl. Something useful. Something practical. In this world now... that's all that matters.

UnitType.Quote: 'The key to our salvation exists in the arcane arts.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: I was born a miner's daughter, friend. Ten children in my family, the only girl... I never thought to see much of this world growing up, but what happened... I was cooking dinner for my father and brothers, they were in the mines, and came a stranger to our door. Had the whitest skin I'd ever seen in my life. Albino, was my guess, though a little darker, he could have been a grayskin. Friendly enough, though, and he was hurt, I could see that, no danger to me... so I gave him food - my father gave him shelter that night, and he was grateful. Kozma, that was the man's name. Strange name, aye. Well the next morning, after the others had gone off to the mines... this man Kozma reached into his pack, see, and handed me a book. First book I'd ever seen in my life. Thick as a loaf of bread, heavy as a brick... written in all these different languages, as it turns out, though of course I couldn't read a word of any of it, back then. "Dying I am, sweet girl. Sweet Linnaid," the man says to me, in this strange accent he had, one I never heard before, or since. "And I have great treasure," he says. "I hoped to bring book to Queen in the West, but Meerdul..." He made a noise then, like he was in pain, and shook his head. "Now I must leave book with you," he says. "Make use of it. Use of it for good. Promise me." Well, I had no idea what he meant by half of that - Queen in the West? Meerdul? - but I promised him. And we spent that day... he read me parts of the book. Taught me some things, and the next day... Kozma, he died. We buried him high up in the hills - dug the grave myself. Well, I kept my promise to him, or tried to, taught myself to read with the help of a friend of mine, at least the parts of the book that were in common tongue, and by and by... well, you see once you learn how big the world is, you just have to go out and see it, don't you? And that's what happened to me. I had to leave the village. Not as if my father understood, but maybe one day... I can go back. I'd like to go back, once I've done as Kozma asked. Used what's in the book for good. That's my aim.

I know my numbers, and my weights and measures as well as any man. When Lord Immerg needed the towers of New Ithul rebuilt, it was me he called on; I was second engineer on the fortress there as well. I ain't afraid of any job, or any man either, for that matter.

There was a man who came to our village, his name was Paoluto... he had heard tell of a kouros, a great library, where the wise men of Atalandra had hidden their greatest treasures... well... I was a young girl, Paoluto was a handsome man, and so... I left with him. We traveled east, and then north, into the wastes, and there we found this kouros, and there... Paoluto died. The great treasures of the past... they have great and powerful guardians. Dangerous guardians. You would do well to keep this in mind, friend, and if you see fit to hire me... I shall surely remind you.

I will tell you that long ago, I was apprenticed to the Azure Knights, intent on joining their ranks myself, though since the time of the Nobles Revolt, the allure of their cause has faded. But the knowledge gained in their service... that burns in my mind still. Knowledge of the Magi's ways... knowledge I will put to the service of a true and well-intentioned leader.

UnitType.Quote: 'I am the wise, for I know that I know nothing...'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: You have a great destiny before you, friend. I sense it. A word of caution, though... greatness can be a curse, as well as a blessing. If you will allow me, I will tell you a story. A story of my village in the time before the Oracle came back to us, before the transformation. I was a farmer then, we were all farmers, to coax food from the land required all to work, but when I was not farming, I was a teacher. My village? No. You would not have heard of it... Sigedd-Belzen, it was called. It no longer exists. Only a few of us remain to remember... Yosku, Czillka... and Meerduul, of course. It is his story I wish to tell you... Meerduul, he was student, I was teacher... we were so close, I have no children of my own, I never married, he was like a son to me. Such brilliance... I have studied the past, I know the great alchemic magics of the old kingdoms, but Meerduul... he did not need to study. To him, these things were second nature. He had greatness within him, you see. Now, what happened - this was a few seasons before the transformation, just before the adventurer from the West, Relias, they called him, came to our land... it was a time of great famine. Great drought. and the villagers of Sigedd-Belzen came to me, for I was loremaster, and asked if there was not a way to use sorcery to restore life to the fields. And I said no. And Meerduul said perhaps. In the Book of Ereog it is written how Az-Adoras, the dark prince, brought death to the lands of Hallas. The grain withered in the field, the fruit withered on the vine, the beasts choked on their own bile. Meerduul knew that the death the dark prince had brought was in fact life energy that had been transformed - perverted to a darker use, and he thought... he believed it was his destiny to restore life to the lands of Sigedd-Belzen. We all told him, you see, that he was meant for greatness, and he believed us. And so he went into the fields, and gathered around him the mana - the energy - he needed to perform this spell of life. And he cast that energy into the earth itself, and tried to draw from it life. And he did. We were so happy, the fields bloomed once more, the grasses grew, there were crops... but only for a short time. A single day. Because the next dawn, when we woke... life had fled the land entirely. Meerduul's spell had drawn the last breath from the fields, and now they were naught but sand, and stone. But that was not the worst thing, my friend. The worst thing was when he wanted to try again. The worst thing was when we had to fight him... to drive him from his home, and his people, for he would not listen to reason. And now he is lost to me, my son, my heir as loremaster. Lost as all of Sigedd-Belzen is lost. That is the story I wished to tell you, about the dangers of greatness.

UnitType.Backstory: A single name is all we are given, we Urxen. From birth, we are raised as fighters, male and female alike. We are given swords upon our ninth birthday, and on our twelfth, if we have not dishonored them, we may take the name of our tribe as well. I am thus Tann of the Dragonborn. In my nineteenth year, I was raised to command. This was ten years ago; in thefifth year of my command came the Black Summer. That plague took all but a handful of my company, and killed all the elders among the Dragonborn. I myself burned the huts of our village, and now... I am a sellsword, yes. But I am Urxen still. A soldier born and bred. I seek the discipline of an army; I seek a sovereign to follow.

UnitType.Quote: I enjoy battles, when the screams of my enemies join in symphony with those in my mind.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: Look not upon this form, mortal. This form does not matter. Look within my eyes to see whose service your coin buys, for in this form dwells the spirit of dread Thannata, who was summoned from the void between worlds by Morrigan himself. In his name I slit the throats of a thousand men, ripped the hearts from brave warriors as they charged upon the battlefield, tore the limbs from their steeds as they tried to flee. Though my flesh rotted long ago, my spirit survived, and thanks to the Patricide's magicks, it can move - I can move - from form to form. This body will soon pass too, though long before it does it will do your cause good service.

GameModifier.Provides: -5% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: 'I am descended from the Northern Wastes, from the men who once worshipped Vetrar as a god.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: You wish to know more about me? I was once heir to a family most noble, a family whose honor and prestige stood second to none in all the land. But all that honor meant nothing to the merchants who my father owed money to; all that honor meant nothing to the mercenaries sent to collect that money. All that honor could not save him. A dozen years ago, I cast aside that honor, and the name that went with it. I make my own honor now; I make my own way in the world.

GameModifier.Provides: -5% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: 'I'll fight for you. For a price.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: Expensive? Let me tell you something, friend. Something I learned when I was very young. Antheros is no more. The Azure Knights are not coming back. It's every man for himself out there, in the wastelands. You need a quick mind, and a quicker blade to survive. Fortunately for you, I have both. Hire me, and your worries are over. Well, perhaps not over, but you'll certainly sleep soundly. As long as you can afford to pay me what I'm worth.

GameModifier.Provides: -5% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: 'I wasn't capable enough back then...I will never say the same again.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory:
I will speak of my past this once alone, so you may know who it is you hire. My mother I never knew. My father was Hanar the Axe, whose name was well-known among the gladiators and nobles who fought in Carrodus's arena. He was the greatest fighter I have ever seen, and yes, I saw Tarth himself as well. Many merchants - many men at arms - lost their fortunes when Hanar fought, because the odds against him always seemed impossible. And yet he would always find a way to win.
That was what killed him you see; a man wagered against my father. This man wagered something he did not ever think he would lose - an artifact of some sort, and when my father won, and it passed from his possession... this man was greatly angered. He came to the longhouse we all shared, afterwards... he called my father out.
"Hanar the Axe, they call you," this man said. "I wonder what it would take to kill you, and yours," and by those words, my father thought this man - who I know now to have been a channeler of great power - my father thought the man meant to kill me, and so he raised his axe. And the man raised his arms, and all at once, there was fire everywhere. Fire filling the air, I was by the cooking pots, which were filled with water to be cleaned since we had just eaten our meal, and I hurled myself within one of those pots,
I was small, and so... I survived. No one else did. So what I have seen, with my own eyes... strength of arms is one thing, and yes, it helps to be strong. I am strong, though I may not look so to your eyes. But since that day my father burned... I have sought out knowledge of sorcery. Knowledge of the great spells which belonged to the Magi of the past, to Hosten, and the Oracle. That knowledge will be yours, if you will hire me.

UnitType.Backstory: Magic is a thing to be feared, friend. It is a primal power whose behavior none can truly understand. I can help predict what a certain spell has tended to achieve in the past, but there are always complicating factors.

UnitType.Backstory: I see it burn in your eyes, friend. The warrior's fire; great glory awaits you. Allow me to join your army; I will vanquish your enemies, and help you tame the wastes once more.

UnitType.Quote: 'Empires and continents rise and fall, only the sea remains.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: We stand on the verge of catastrophe, my friend. The grayskins seek to extend their dominion over the entirety of this world, and we - all the tribes of man, all the countries, all the races, - must band together to stop them. We must pool the knowledge we have in this fight, yes, even that which the scholars of ages past called the black arts. For surely our foes will use those weapons themselves.

UnitType.Quote: 'Don't tell me there's no one left to fight.'

UnitType.Backstory: I've got the blood of the Aivernach in my veins, on my father's side. But I'd rather swing a hammer than make one, friend. It's my aim to see the world, or what's left of it, in the years I have left to me.

UnitType.Quote: 'Grrrrr...'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory:
Most scholars believe that demons were created by the cataclysm, that they are elementals, pure forms of the world's power that was bound, corrupted and twisted by Curgen. That they were driven mad, that they have come to hate things of flesh and delight in the pain and suffering of those that have reduced their world to ruin.
But evidence of demons stretches well back before the cataclysm. There are stories of creatures that Arnor Tandis battled outside of Gemend that are unlike anything the world has known. The Pits of Grazna are said to contain creatures which feed on madness and sorrow and whose hunger will one day grow to consume the world. And the dark vassal of Lady Umber is mentioned as well, a creature that resembles the beasts of the Jungles of Khaffar, an eternal predator who passes silently between trees, shadows and worlds.
The creatures name is Ascian and the tome says that it served Lady Umber as an assassin because she bound the creature to her with an Amethyst Collar. Since the fall of Umber the creature is said to be free in the world, hunting as it desires and dragging those it stalks into endless darkness.

GameModifier.Provides: -5% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: 'This world is mine.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: Once, he was a holy man. A Son of the Dragon; a worshipper of Elemental's most primal, powerful creatures. Their warden; their protector. Then Curgen sent the slave armies of the Quendar after Waerloga and his charges; in response, Waerloga took up the Scepter of Tan-La-Ur, and bound the dragons to his will. For seven long, bloody years, he waged war against the armies of Imperium; a war that ended with his defeat, and imprisonment within the darkest of all Curgen's dungeons, the Pit of Lost Voices. There are some who say he waits there still, brooding and silent, seeking only the chance to win his escape, and wreak vengeance upon the world.

UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: Fighting's what I do. It's all that I know how to do. Fought Tarth himself to a draw once, in the Arena. And Badra. She says she never lost a fight, but she would've lost to me if the baron's wife hadn't've put her nose in it. Figure now's when I should make some coin off what I do.

UnitType.Quote: 'I will guard only those who are worthy.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: It is a unique weapon I offer in your service, stranger. Here - I will show you. You can see, the metal itself... it burns, yes, but it is not consumed. If it touches flesh, though... I myself am immune to it, of course. How the blade was enchanted? No, I cannot say. The weapon was given to me by my father - he was - he is - Galain Gaelsen. The hero of Thela's Peak, yes. A great knight, yes. We no longer speak. It is my service you are buying. Ulrik Gaelsen. I have commanded in battle as well.

GameModifier.Provides: -5% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: If you are patient enough, your prey will come to you.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: The first thing you should know about me is that my grandfather commanded the Imperial bodyguard, in the time before the Cataclysm. He made the Long March, and died with honor when the Emperor fell. His blood flows in my veins; the memory of his deeds burns in my mind, and inspires me. It is because of him that I found this staff; it is because of him that I know how to wield it. It is my duty to seek out the descendants of those who slew him, and repay them in kind. It is a destiny I will fulfill. Some call me braggart for speaking in such a manner. Should you be wise enough to pay my fee, to hire my services, you will discover I am simply speaking truth.

GameModifier.Provides: -5% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: You should not summon unless you can control? But how are you to practice control except by summoning?'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory:
Where ever I went fire followed me. First in the destruction of my home and the loss of my parents, and later choking black cloud that consumed the orphanage I was raised in. And I know your thoughts, neither was my doing.
As a young man I was apprenticed to a smith and I was the least surprised to see fire coming again, this time on the heads of Umbrian arrows. The other villagers stupidly attempted to put out the fires, making them easy targets for the archers. Some tried to escape, but the Umbrian raiders waited for them in the darkness.
I ran into the fire, into the great council house at the village's center. Its thatched roof blazed like a new sun, the walls would fuel the fire for hours. Burning sedge fell down around me like demonic rain. I could hear the raiders moving through the village, I could hear their sharp, guttural voices. I could hear their hate.
And I could hear other voices too. As hungry and eager as the Umbrian raiders, as eager to pillage and consume. I had hundreds of burns and I thought I would never get the taste of smoke out of my throat. I screamed and the voices screamed back.
But in the morning the raiders were gone and I was the only one alive, though I wasn't alone. I could still hear the fires whispers, and when I bid them come, they obeyed.

GameModifier.Provides: -5% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: The only commodity more valuable than life is gildar.'
UnitType.NPCRecruitmentText: I can be of service. If you wish to hire me for %d gildar.
UnitType.Backstory: My name is Pralius, friend. I was of the Dragonborn, a great legion we were. Strong fighters. We struck as one, in battle. Then came the Black Summer. All was lost then. My wife... what happened to her. She suffered, friend, until I could stand her suffering no more. I did what I had to, but I know this. That was no ordinary plague. It was sorcery - dark sorcery, and I know who was responsible. I will find him, and when I do... you see my sword? The blade is not metal, no. I do not know what it is, exactly, it was fashioned for me... careful, do not touch. It is quite toxic. I shall use it in your service, happily, when the need arises. But know that I shall bury it in the heart of he who is responsible for my wife's death when I find him. But fear not. I have other weapons to put at your disposal.

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Henchmen level and can use equipment like champions, but don't divide experience.
A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

UnitType.Description: The least of Magnar society.
UnitType.Backstory: Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: A peasant with a stick.
UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
A spearman is effective against well armored enemies.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: Relias was orphaned when his clan's camp was set ablaze by wandering thieves. Finding a new home with a caring scholar, Relias focused his attention on the books that surrounded him. Those stories sent his mind racing between dreams of heroism and the harsh reality of the sword.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
You were born the pampered son of a noble; the first two dozen years of your life, you wasted in the city of New Pariden, drinking, gaming, whoring, running through every last bit of the fortune your parents bequeathed you before being conscripted into the service of Queen Procipinee. At her command, you journeyed East, into the lands of the Fallen, where you learned first-hand the power of the Channelers that rule that dark and devastated continent.
You know that power will not rest until all of Elemental is subjugated to its will. The power of the West must join together to confront that evil; you are determined to lead them in that fight.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: Born somewhere in the Central Wastelands to parents he no longer remembers, Carrodus made his way to the city of Ruvenna as a youth. He worked as a pickpocket until he was old enough to be trained as a soldier in service to the Merchant-Lords of Surrane and Calder. He is a natural fighter and an inspiring leader of men.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
When the scribes write the history of these times - when they tell the tale of how, from the ashes of the Cataclysm, civilization arose once more - you are determined your name will figure prominently in their accounts.
It will be the story of the triumph of will - your will. Of a young boy who never knew his parents, an orphan raised on the streets of ruined Ruvenna, a soldier of prodigious fighting ability who rose to command, who made himself not just a master of arms, but an adept in the channeler's art.
Your first step on the road to writing that history begins now.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: In the Temple of Destiny, in the center of once-great Cyndrum, the Oracle Ceresa can be found, wisest amongst the Fallen. She speaks for the last of the titans, the Dread Lord Talax. The oracle performs magics of the highest difficulty and pronounces prophecies for her people and those who seek her council.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
You were born long ago, in the north of Anthys, a simple child, of simple people. But the gods blessed you with a gift - the ability to foretell the future. It was a blessing you neither asked for, nor desired. It took you from your home, to Odenvell, where warlords and statesmen, mages and masters-at-arms alike, came to the Temple raised in your honor bowing down before you, asking for your favor. But you shunned the power you had been given, and sought only solitude.
Now you seek more. The world has changed, and you have changed with it. Power, you see now, is your birthright - your heritage - your destiny. You will use it to restore order to the world's chaos... and raise an Empire that will last a thousand years.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: This warrior-queen is the only child of the great Gladiator Tarth, for whom the country she now leads was named. Irane is, in many ways, her father's physical twin. She has the same features and is, in full armor, virtually the same size. Her entire life was spent living in his shadow; his presence, and absence, shaped her every action.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
Your father was Tarth the Valiant, who led the gladiators' rebellion that freed the slaves of the north. From the time you were old enough to hold a sword, you stood at his right hand in his war councils, and rode at his side into battle.
Now Tarth is dead - and the mantle of leadership, you feel, should pass to you. But many of those who followed him have so far been reluctant to raise your banners. They ignore your fighting skills - and the channeler's abilities you have only recently developed.
This you are determined to change. For as your youth belies your years of experience in battle, your fragile appearance belies your inner steel.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: Karavox claims lineage from Warlord Kraxis, slayer of Emperor Amarian. None are certain of which race, man or Fallen, he was truly born. What is certain is that he is no ordinary being, but rather a channeler of surpassing abilities. With his magics he razed the great palace at Goyarh Hedigah, such is his might.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
Men of the West call you a traitor. They say you have betrayed the principles of mankind - nobility, honor, fairness. They look down upon you with contempt, and say they will never trust the Krax again.
They are fools.
History shows it was the Amarian who abandoned the Krax - who left your armies to stand alone in the East. Your grandfather and father, your friends and neighbors died fighting for the race of man; you are determined not to share their fate. You will forge a new Kraxis, one that stands apart from all others, men and Fallen alike- a civilization destined to be spoken of in the same breath as the kingdoms of Hallas and Malaya, of Al-Ashteroth and fabled Antheros.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: Kulan is the leader of a great Fallen empire that survived the Cataclysm, and a channeler of dark magics. Some say that he is neither Man or Fallen but a hybrid. And some go further and say that he was not born but spawned by Morrigan the Damned, within the caverns of lost Calebethon.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
You do not know who - or what - you are.
Your earliest memories are of Calebethon, and the great laboratories of Morrigan the Mad, deep in the caverns of this world. There are some who say you were made there, that you are not truly Fallen, as you appear, but a creature forged of equal parts man, and Urxen warrior. For centuries, you lived in that darkness, apprenticed to the mad Emperor, serving as his assistant in all matters of necromancy and science.
When Morrigan died, you made your way to Cyndrum, where you served the Lady Umber until she perished in the cataclysm. Now you seek to raise an Empire of your own.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: Magnar is Fallen, ancient beyond reckoning. He is said to be descended of the first Magnar, who was the first of the Fallen created by the Dread Lord, thousands of years in the past. He rules over the city of Imperium and knows the secrets of the Dread Lord.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
You are eldest of all who now walk this world.
You stood at Curgen's side as he raised Imperium to the highest of heights; you watched as the awesome energies of the cataclysm destroyed the great Empire he had created. For a hundred years you have waited, and gathered your strength. You have apprenticed to the Black Sorcerer, and withstood the fires of the Veladrii's forge; you have trained with the commanders of the Quendar, sharpening your already-considerable fighting skills.
Now it is your time. You are ready to raise an Empire of your own; to discipline those savages wreaking havoc upon the land, and restore honor to those tribes who will pay homage to you.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: Born in the shadow of the Skarps, raised by miners turned subsistence farmers, Enil Markinn was the catalyst behind the rebirth of the Miners Guild. He was also the first among their number to actively seek out trade for their ore in the cities surrounding Lake Zabril.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
You were born into the hardscrabble life of a miner, like your father and grandfather before. By the time you were ten years old, you were digging in the Skarps, in the vast tunnels carved by the Aivernach. At thirty you became leader of your clan; six months later, on an expedition south, you became lost in the jungles of Zad-Zabril.
Your sojourn lasted nearly a decade. In that time you became a master of the channeler's art and saw many wondrous things. The glories of the past were made manifest to you: the bridges of Neshin, the temples of lost Zabril. You are determined to restore those monuments and build ones of your own, in the process writing your name - and the name of your people - in the history books of Elemental.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: Daughter of Amarian III, Queen Procipinee of New Pariden remains the greatest channeler of the New Age. Her powers have been instrumental in restoring life to the shattered lands surrounding her capital city, and in keeping that city safe from monsters and wicked men alike.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
You are Procipinee, sole survivor of the royal family that once ruled the Free Cities of the North.
Your father was Amarian III - Amarian the Sojourner. He bequeathed to you not just his abilities as a channeler, but a strong sense of responsibility. It is your duty, you feel, to use your gifts in the service of others, to make the lives of those less fortunate, less gifted than yourself, better. You would restore the Golden Age of the Magi... bring the benefits of that civilization to all of Elemental - including races other than men, if they would accept your leadership.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Backstory: Verga is the most fearsome of all Fallen in the East. He stands as a full 10 feet high, carries a pair of axes that he can butcher an ox with in a few minutes. It takes less time to do the same to a man. His might is prodigious, as is his skill with weaponry. His fighters are trained as well, and obey his orders without question.
UnitType.LorebookIntroText:
Many things are said of you; that your own mother called you monster, and cast you out from your home. That you were raised by wargs in the Asag, and rose to command the pack. Some of those things are true; none of them matter. To you, words are wind. Pretty speeches win no wars. Strength does. Strength of arms, magic and will.
At the age of fifteen, you crossed Kharrazan's Fist in search of the Trog who murdered your brother. For nineteen days, you marched across the desert sands, until you found the killer and his companions. Most you killed with your knife, or their own weapons; the murderer, you ripped apart with your bare hands. The rest follow you now, as all others will soon. None can withstand your power. Those who will not yield will die. Those who survive will serve.

UnitType.Description: Caravans boost your economy by allowing merchants in your cities to trade goods with each other.

UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: The Galadwenn are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance. The claim to trace their ancestry to air spirits and though that is unlikely, their grace is amazing.
UnitType.Backstory: These are the archers of Pariden, Amarians who are masters of the bow, trained in the same manner and using the same drills as the Ninety-Nine of Redstone. And no wonder - for their namesake, Galadwenn of the Free Cities, was himself heir to the Bow of Ydrain, said to have been used by Argynn in his war against the tribes of the Khulan.

All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Dross Archers are lightly equipped and count on numbers to kill their opponents. The Quendar believe that a bow makes one an archer, and they are quick to hand them out to untrained units when war requires.
UnitType.Backstory: Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

UnitType.Description: The Clan of the Crow are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance. Among the archers of Elemental the Clan is the most reknown for their skill.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

Within the catacombs of ruined Odenvell, Ceresa took dozens of these carnivorous spiders and bound them to her will. Study of the proper enchantments will enable those who are flesh of her flesh - those who the world calls Wraiths - to similarly enslave these deadly arachnids, and use them as weapons against their enemies.

UnitType.Description: Catapults are devastating on the battle field but are extremely slow and expensive. Their attacks damage all units within a 1 tile radius.
UnitType.Backstory: These machines are based upon drawings found in the great library at New Pariden. They are reconstructions of those catapults Argynn used thousands of years ago during the siege of Eduruun V'olloz - the black citadel of the Nerazga.

"I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

"It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: The Unfalling Legion are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage. They are well trained guardians and armies that include them will benefit from their protection.
UnitType.Backstory:
These are the elite soldiers of the Krax army, who receive both their training and their unit names in the citadel of the Warrior, in the heart of Tanacabra. According to Janusk of Krandir, those youths who enter the citadel break off all contact with their families, change their names, and pledge their lives to the service of the Emperor Karavox.
According to Karavox's ambassadors, none of that is true.

UnitType.Description: Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. UnitType.Description: The Sentinels of Hagudst are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage. Their decades of experience guarding some of the darkest places of Elemental has granted them a somber view of the world.
UnitType.Backstory: These are the eyes of the Enchantress; those fighters charged as Resoln's first line of defense against invaders. According to Gradzh of Hedigah, sole survivor of Kraxis's failed attempt to seize the city of Maz Galuur in the south of that country, these sentinels have been bewitched; their lifespans shortened by half, in order that they may serve without the need for sleep.

Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Barons are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: Barons are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Barons are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Barons are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Barons are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Harbingers of War are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range. They are the most elite of the Trog armies and not many can withstand their attacks.
UnitType.Backstory:
"The sound of their boots upon the city's cobblestones shall haunt my dreams, in this life and the next." - Hengut the Younger of Odenvell.
Trog heavy infantry. The armies of the Titans of old - the endless swarms of soldiers depicted in the great paintings and murals recovered from Imperium's ruins - were often led by units similar to these, whose appearance foretold the coming of battle, of death and destruction.

"It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: Bards level and use equipment like champions. They can learn basic air and water spells and improve the rate the army they are in gains experience.
Shieldmen level and use equipment like champions. They can learn basic earth spells and help defend the armies they are in.
Torch Bearers level and use equipment like champions. They can learn basic fire and life spells and improve the healing of the army they are in.

As compared to other faction's horsemen the Knights are known for their speed and are often able to sweep over enemy spellcasters and archers before they have a chance to act.

UnitType.Description: The Marrowguard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. They are driven into a frenzy at the smell of blood and many commanders use archers to direct their attacks.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: The Tide of Teeth are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. The Tide is known for nipping at the heels of powerful enemies. The tactic is frequently suicide, but unquestioningly effective.
UnitType.Backstory:
"Now you are the whirlwind; warg and rider, one flesh from two. Reap me a harvest of bright, red blood." - The Enchantress
These are mounted units of the Wraith army; warriors upon wargs, whose unearthly speed and savage ferocity have given rise to rumors of cannibalism upon the battliefield.

These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: There are few creatures on Elemental that are able to withstand more damage than an Iron Golem. Long have they stood silent, patient sentry over their charges.
UnitType.Backstory: These are creatures forged of mana and metal; beings who can be summoned into existence only by those possessing the blood of the Aivernach - the Iron Tribes of old. An Iron Golem can wield any weapon given to it, and is a master of defense; long after the last men of Aivern fell to the hordes of Meergas Maz Adul's Nerazga, its Iron Golems remained, stalwart protectors of the city walls.

UnitType.Description: Nothing matches the savagery of a Juggernaut. Your enemies should be afraid, but your allies are also at risk from the Juggernaut's frenzied attacks.
UnitType.Backstory: "Feel no pain. Know no fear. Need no rest. Fight till the foe falls. Then seek the next battle." These are the watchwords of the yatra nata - the Juggernauts - the elite among all Trog warriors, soldiers segregated from their brethren on their eleventh name day for special training. History says their first battle came a dozen years after the Quendar conquered Teroth-Nu, when eight of them overthrew a city full of Magnar II's troops, and retook Kir-Tion's throne.

UnitType.Description: The Redwatch are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles. They learn faster than other faction's warriors and can become experienced units after only a few battles.

UnitType.Description: Carrion Men are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles. Although dangerous from the start they are even more dangerous when injured, often flying into a berserk rage.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Axeman are good early skirmishers, though they can't wield shields their Cleave ability allows them to attack multiple enemies at once.
UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Mages deal magical damage at range, use them to decimate enemies that rely on physical defense.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: Mages deal magical damage at range, use them to decimate enemies that rely on physical defense.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Mages deal magical damage at range, use them to decimate enemies that rely on physical defense.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.
